title: Bilateral Progressive Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Cookie-Bite Configuration)
chief_complaint: I am having difficulty hearing the students I teach in the classroom. I also struggle to hear my husband and soft voices.

problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty performing job duties (teaching) and communicating at home.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to hear better in the classroom.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral, progressive hearing loss over several years.
history.medical_psych_history: Family history of hearing loss (mother and grandmother).
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing for teaching and daily communication.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss with a 'cookie-bite' configuration. Thresholds are within normal limits at 250 Hz, slope to a slight-to-mild loss in the mid-frequencies (500-1500 Hz), and rise back to within normal limits in the high frequencies (2000-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA, indicating a mild loss in the ability to receive speech. Word recognition scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal middle ear function (Type A). Left ear shows reduced compliance (Type As/hypocompliant).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ear reflexes (ipsi/contra) are within normal limits. Left ear reflexes are abnormal (elevated or absent) likely due to the middle ear stiffness (hypocompliance). Reflex decay was negative where measurable.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetric, low-to-mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss (often called a 'cookie-bite' configuration), rising to normal hearing in the high frequencies. Speech recognition is excellent. The configuration and strong family history suggest a genetic etiology. The left ear shows slight middle ear stiffness (Type As tympanogram), affecting acoustic reflex thresholds, but the primary deficit is sensorineural.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss has a unique 'cookie-bite' shape, meaning you hear very low and very high pitch sounds well, but miss the middle pitches where a lot of speech volume is.
Given your family history (mother and grandmother), this pattern is likely genetic.
Because your high-pitch hearing is good, you retain clarity, but voices may sound hollow or lacking volume.

Hearing aids are recommended to boost the mid-range volumes specifically. Receiver-in-the-canal (RIC) style aids would work well to keep your ear canal open for the natural high-pitch hearing you still have.
notes_for_actor: You are a teacher who is frustrated by missing student questions.
You are generally healthy and have no dizziness or ear pain.
You are aware your mother and grandmother had hearing loss, so you might not be surprised by the diagnosis.
